column1: The Ming Empire took control of Liaoning in 1371
column2: just three years after the expulsion of the Mongols from Beijing. Around 1442
column3: a defense wall was constructed to defend the agricultural heartland of the province from a potential threat from the Jurchen-Mongol Oriyanghan (who were Ming's tributaries) from the northwest. Between 1467 and 1468
column4: the wall was expanded to protect the region from the northeast as well
column5: against attacks from Jianzhou Jurchens (who were later to become known as the Manchu people). Although similar in purpose to the Great Wall of China
column6: this "Liaodong Wall" was of a lower-cost design. While stones and tiles were used in some parts
column7: most of the wall was in fact simply an earth dike with moats on both sides.

column19: reminding of the necessity to do something with illegal migrants ... In any event

column1: Liaoning was one of the first provinces in China to industrialize
column2: first under Japanese occupation
column3: and then even more in the 1950s and 1960s. The city of Anshan
column5: is home to one of the largest iron and steel complexes in China. In recent years
column6: this early focus on heavy industry has become a liability
column7: as many of the large state-run enterprises have experienced economic difficulties. Recognizing the special difficulties faced by Liaoning and other provinces in Northeast China because of their heritage of heavy industry
column8: the Chinese central government recently launched a "Revitalize the Northeast" Campaign.

column1: It is possible to think of Liaoning as three approximate geographical regions: the highlands in the west

column3: and hills in the east.

column1: The highlands in the west are dominated by the Nulu'erhu Mountains

column2: Daliao

column3: Mount Huabozi (1336 m)

column1: Liaoning has a continental monsoon climate
column2: and rainfall averages to about 440 to 1130 mm annually. Summer is rainy while the other seasons are dry.

column1: Liaoning contains some of the foremost paleontological sites in the world. Known collectively as the Jehol Group
column2: they include the Yixian Formation
column3: Jiufotang Formation and Tiaojishan Formation. The name Jehol derives from a now defunct provincial division of that name
column4: which covered an area that is now Western Liaoning
column5: Eastern Hebei
column6: and a small part of Inner Mongolia. Fossils were first found there during the 1920s. During the Japanese occupation of the area through the 1930s and early 1940s
column8: but records of them were lost after World War II ended. The area remained relatively unexplored until the 1990s. It was in 1996 that Liaoning made the headlines with the announcement of the discovery of Sinosauropteryx prima
column9: the first example of a filamented "feathered" dinosaur. Sinosauropteryx prima was a small feathered meat-eating dinosaur
column10: from the Lower Cretaceous Yixian Formation. This discovery pushed the evolution of feathers back in time and showed that dinosaurs
column12: had feathers. It also showed a direct evolutionary link between theropod dinosaurs and modern birds.

column2: dozens of ground-breaking finds have been discovered throughout the Jehol group. These including the earliest flower
column3: earliest eutherian mammal
column5: the earliest known metatherian
column6: an intact embryo of a pterosaur
column7: Repenomamus robustus—a 15 kg heavy mammal that ate dinosaurs
column9: as well as many birds and feathered dinosaurs. Discoveries such as Dilong paradoxus
column11: date to the early Cretaceous Period. This is some 60 million years before Tyrannosaurus
column12: and thus these discoveries push the evolution of feathers earlier than previously thought.The Liaoning fossils are noted for their high degree of preservation—often including soft body tissues
column13: which is rare. Aside from the famous birds and feathered dinosaurs
column17: and plants. The Liaoning deposit is widely considered to be the one of the world's premier fossil sites. The high level of preservation is believed to be due to how the animals died. The area was volcanically active
column18: and large plumes of volcanic dust repeatedly covered the area
column19: instantly killing and burying any living thing in the area. The extremely fine grain of the sediment and the chemical composition of the ash prevented the usual bacterial decay. In some specimens
column20: extremely fine details can be seen such as the proboscis of the bee Florinemestruis used to drink nectar from the earliest flowers. In other specimens
column22: including stripes on fish and spots on turtles.

column1: The politics of Liaoning is structured in a single party-government system like all other governing institutions in mainland China. The Governor of Liaoning (辽宁省省长) is the highest-ranking official in the People's Government of Liaoning. However

The Central Liaoning city cluster is a megalopolis centered on Shenyang (urban population 4 million). Within its 150 km (93 mi) radius
column2: it includes Anshan (urban population 1.3 million)
